title: Francesco Libetta
text:
Francesco Libetta (born 16 October 1968) is an Italian <a href="pianist">pianist</a>, <a href="composer">composer</a> and <a href="Conducting">conductor</a>.
Biography.
Born in <a href="Galatone">Galatone</a>, <a href="Southern%20Italy">Southern Italy</a>, Francesco Libetta studied music in Italy (piano with <a href="Vittoria%20De%20Donno">Vittoria De Donno</a>; contrapoint with <a href="Cosimo%20Colazzo">Cosimo Colazzo</a> and <a href="Igino%20Ettorre">Igino Ettorre</a>; composition with <a href="Gino%20Marinuzzi">Gino Marinuzzi</a>; conducting with <a href="Alberto%20Maria%20Giuri">Alberto Maria Giuri</a>) and in <a href="France">France</a> (composition with <a href="Jacques%20Cast%C3%A9r%C3%A8de">Jacques Castérède</a>). He moved to <a href="Lecce">Lecce</a>, where he has taught <a href="Chamber%20Music">Chamber Music</a> at the "T. Schipa" Conservatory.
Described as a "poet-aristocrat of the keyboard with the profile and the carriage of a Renaissance prince" (M. Gurewitsch, "<a href="New%20York%20Times">New York Times</a>"), he first came to the attention of piano <a href="Connoisseur">cognoscenti</a> after his live performance of 53 Studies by <a href="Godowsky">Godowsky</a> based on the 27 Studies by Chopin. Performances included: 1990 in <a href="Galatina">Galatina</a>; then 1994/95 in <a href="Milan">Milan</a>; <a href="Naples">Naples</a>, <a href="Florence">Florence</a>; 2006 in Milan; 2010 one day in <a href="Bras%C3%ADlia">Brasília</a>. Libetta's <a href="repertoire">repertoire</a> now encompasses a very wide range, including all of <a href="Beethoven">Beethoven</a>'s 32 piano <a href="sonatas">sonatas</a> (performed first in Italy, 1993/94), several <a href="Mozart">Mozart</a> and Beethoven concertos, the complete <a href="Handel">Handel</a> and <a href="Chopin">Chopin</a> works, as well as major works by <a href="Schubert">Schubert</a>, <a href="Robert%20Schumann">Schumann</a>, <a href="Debussy">Debussy</a>, and <a href="Ravel">Ravel</a>.
He is active as a conductor (in symphonic repertoire, as well as collaborating with the <a href="Balletto%20del%20Sud">Balletto del Sud</a> in major <a href="Tchaikovsky">Tchaikovsky</a> ballets). He is also a composer. His works include three piano <a href="concerto">concerto</a>s, symphonic pieces, <a href="electronic%20music">electronic music</a>, and <a href="ballet">ballet</a> and movie scores. His writings include historical and aesthetic essays.
In 2005 he had a short role in <a href="Franco%20Battiato">Franco Battiato</a>'s movie "<a href="Musikanten">Musikanten</a>", on Beethoven's life.
In 2009, his first <a href="opera">opera</a> was premiered. "Ottocento" ("Eight Hundred", about 800 victims of <a href="religious%20war">religious war</a> in South Italy in 1480) was performed in <a href="Otranto">Otranto</a> and <a href="Rome">Rome</a>.
<a href="John%20Ardoin">John Ardoin</a> declared that among the new generation of pianists, Francesco Libetta is "the most inspired and creative".
One of his DVDs, with the recording of a recital held at the <a href="Festival%20de%20La%20Roque-d%27Anth%C3%A9ron">Festival de La Roque-d'Anthéron</a> (France), created by <a href="Bruno%20Monsaingeon">Bruno Monsaingeon</a>, was awarded the <a href="Diapason%20d%27Or">Diapason d'Or</a> and the "CHOC" of "<a href="Le%20Monde%20de%20la%20musique">Le Monde de la musique</a>".
Critics have praised his qualities: ". . .elegance and charm, (...), with a hint, a touch of aristocratic frivolity that we did not think we would ever witness again." (F. M. Colombo - "<a href="Corriere%20della%20Sera">Corriere della Sera</a>"); ". . . a breadth of knowledge that extends far beyond the world of music and the piano repertoire." (A. Mandelli - "PianoTime"); ". . . such miraculous virtuosity and such a delicate feel for melody that one cannot help wondering whether any other artist of his generation - whether in Italy or elsewhere - can be compared to him." (P. Isotta - "Corriere della Sera").
He was Artistic Director of the <a href="Miami%20Piano%20Festival">Miami Piano Festival</a> in Lecce (a summer festival which brings to Lecce musicians, professors and students from all over the world since July 2003) and of the <a href="Michelangeli%20Festival">Michelangeli Festival</a> in Rabbi. He has published essays on history and aesthetics, including music by Renaissance composers, reconstructions of <a href="Madrigal%20%28music%29">Madrigal</a>s, cultural life in the late eighteenth century, etc.
